title: Climate vandal ripped to shreds by judge who tells him to ‘get a job’
text:
Joseph O’Malley, 33, was told that it wasn’t a protest, it was just vandalism (Picture: PA)

A volunteer tree planter has been ordered by a judge to seek employment after he sprayed graffiti onto a war memorial honouring women.

Joseph O’Malley, 33, wrote the word ‘mother’ on the 23ft sculpture during an Extinction Rebellion demonstration along Whitehall last November.

O’Malley appeared at Westminster Magistrates’ Court in clothes that were too big for him, a wooden beaded necklace and shoes that were ripped open.

District Judge Richard Blake slammed him saying: ‘It wasn’t protest, it was just vandalism. The manner in which you attacked this memorial was a senseless expression of the word “mother”.

‘For some reason, on this protest you involved yourself in hooliganism and vandalism. It was senseless.

It took two months for the graffiti to be removed from the statue (Picture: Rex Shutterstock)

O’Malley appeared in court in clothes that were too big for him and shoes that had ripped open (Picture: PA)

‘I fail to see how defacing a significant monument which recognises the role of women in our society, for too many decades overlooked, in overcoming the tyranny of Nazism, how defacing this memorial can in any way further the cause of those who seek to bring to our attention concerns about climate change.’

He added: ‘There’s no reason I’m told you could not get employment. You’re going to need to find some work to pay this off.’

He was found guilty of causing criminal damage in his absence when he failed to turn up at court earlier this year.

Defending, Chantel Gaber said: ‘His intention wasn’t to damage that memorial. It wasn’t intended to cause offence.

‘It was impulsive during the march. There was no long-term damage. The damage was temporary and minimal.’

The memorial commemorates the work done by millions of British women during the war (Picture: PA)

Other protesters tried to clean off the graffiti, but it could not be removed for two months (Picture: Rex Shutterstock)

Vandal O’Malley was a little shy as he left Westminster Magistrates’ Court after being told to get a job (Picture: PA)

The judge ordered O’Malley, of Manor Way, Ruislip, to pay a £500 fine, a £50 victim surcharge, and £200 costs – a total of £750.

The Monument to the Women of the Second World War, near Downing Street and the Cenotaph, commemorates the work done by millions of British women who signed up for the armed services and in factories to bolster the war effort.

The monument was unveiled by the Queen in 2005, 60 years on from the end of the conflict which scarred Europe.

Designed by John Mills, it depicts the hung-up uniforms and working clothes of female munitions workers and servicewomen.

Ms Gaber said O’Malley was jobless and carried out volunteer work, including tree-planting for a group called Fellowship of the Trees.

It was not possible to get a precise figure for the cost of removing the spray paint from the memorial, which remained on the sculpture for around two months, the court heard.

Protesters camped around the memorial during recent protests (Picture: Reuters)

The memorial was previously vandalised during anti-austerity protests that broke out in London (Picture: Rex Shutterstock)
description: Volunteer tree planter Joseph O'Malley appeared at court in clothes that were too big for him, a wooden beaded necklace and shoes that were ripped open.
